idCitation.resTitle: Isothermality for the Continental U.S., derived from 800-meter 30-year Climate Normals (1971-2000)

citRespParty.rpOrgName: U.S. Geological Survey, Fort Collins Science Center (FORT)
U.S. Geological Survey, Fort Collins Science Center (FORT)

dataIdInfo.idAbs: Staff at the U.S. Geological Survey, Fort Collins Science Center developed this data set using 800-meter, 30-year climate normals data created by the PRISM Climate Group at Oregon State University. The data set represents a continuous raster surface of isothermality (a measure of the difference between day/night temperatures relative to the difference between summer/winter temperatures) for the continental United States. The original data for this raster came from multiple climate station point measurements. Using these station measurements, the PRISM Climate Group produced interpolated climate grids for each month in the 30-year period between 1971 and 2000, which became the inputs in the algorithm used by the USGS to derive the data set. The values within the data set are found using an algorithmic calculation that is performed on a cell-by-cell basis. Calculations consider only the relevant inputs for the individual raster cell in question. Climate data can be represented and disseminated in different ways: as time-series data or as normalized data. Time-series data represent static recordings for a particular period (i.e., average highest temperature for a particular month from a particular year). For example, time-series climate data for the month of January over a 10 year period will consist of 10 separate data sets-- one for each year. Normalized data (or 'normals') represent averaged climatic measurements for a specified period (i.e., the average highest temperature for a particular month is recorded every year for the time period in question, and all of those values are subsequently averaged-- or normalized). For example, normalized climate data for the month of January over a 10 year period will consist of only one data set. The difference between time-series and normalized climate data should be noted and taken into consideration when using and interpreting climate data sets. *THE INFORMATION CONTAINED IN THIS RASTER LAYER WAS DERIVED FROM NORMALIZED CLIMATE INPUTS.*
dataIdInfo.idPurp: Isothermality is generally useful for tropical, insular, and maritime environments. Isothermality is derived by calculating the ratio of the mean diurnal range (Bio 2) to the annual temperature range (Bio 7), and then multiplying by 100. Isothermality therefore quantifies how large the day-to-night temperatures oscillate relative to the summer-to-winter (annual) oscillations. An isothermal value of 100 indicates the diurnal temperature range is equivalent to the annual temperature range, while anything less than 100 indicates a smaller level of temperature variability within a month relative to the year. A species distribution may therefore be influenced by larger or smaller fluctuations within a month relative to the year and this variable is useful for ascertaining such information. Values calculated using the following formula: Step 1. Divide Bio 2 (Mean Diurnal Range) by Bio 7 (Temperature Annual Range). Step 2. Multiply the result of Step 1 by 100. This bioclimatic variable corresponds to Bio3 of the WorldClim variables.

dataExt.exDesc: Climatological period from which the point observations were taken.

dataIdInfo.suppInfo: Many species are affected by both climatic and non-climatic factors. Climate changes can impose physiological constraints on species and therefore can affect species distributions to varying degrees. The relationship between climate and most species varies due to local adaptation and other factors limiting distribution, such as dispersion constraints related to habitat availability. The bioclimatic variables are typically used as predictors for species distribution models, which can provide information about the spatial and temporal variations of limiting climatic factors for ecological applications. Bioclimatic variables/predictors are derived from a combination of climatic factors (minimum/maximum temperature and total precipitation) and can be useful for identifying species’ potential ranges. These variables capture information about annuals (annual mean temperature, annual precipitation) and seasonal mean climate conditions (annual range in temperature and precipitation), as well as climate extremes and intra-year seasonality (temperature of the coldest and warmest months, precipitation of the wettest and driest quarters). These variables are often used in species distribution modeling to represent temperatures and precipitation values, beyond basic monthly and annual averages, that exist for any given cell. These values represent environmental conditions important for plants or animals to grow and survive. It is important to examine the species of interest when determining which bioclimatic variables will be most useful in an analysis. The 19 bioclimatic variables developed by WorldClim serve as a starting place for species distribution modeling. Given the nuances of any given species, additional bioclimatic variables are often derived from the total precipitation and minimum / maximum temperature variables. The minimum and maximum monthly temperature define either a single month for a specific year (time-series) or a mean of a single month across a span of years (normals). The total monthly precipitation defines either a single month for a specific year (time-series) or the mean total of a single month across a span of years (normals). When we use maximum/minimum temperature and precipitation, we actually are referring to the mean or mean total climatic factors as described here.

dqReport.measDesc: All data were based on the same averaging period (1971-2000). Similar quality assurance procedures were used with all input data sets.

Data considered complete for static climatic measurements from 1971-2000. Point estimates of climatic variables originated from some or all of the following sources: 1) National Weather Service (NWS) Cooperative (COOP)stations 2) Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS) SNOTEL 3) United States Forest Service (USFS) and Bureau of Land Management (BLM) RAWS Stations 4) Bureau of Reclamation (AGRIMET) stations 5) California Data Exchange Center (CDEC) stations 6) Storage guages 7) NRCS Snowcourse stations 8) Other State and local station networks 9) Estimated station data 10) Upper air stations 11) NWS/Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) Automated surface observation stations (ASOS) 12) Canadian Stations All COOP station data were subjected to quality control checks by the National Climatic Data Center (NCDC). All COOP, SNOTEL and other data were subjected to further quality control checks by the PRISM Climate Group.

The accuracy of this layer is limited by the accuracy of the input climate data, but calculations can be considered accurate based on the data used. The multiple input layers and difference in the variable weighting used to calculate climatic values in the original PRISM climate data made a single accuracy assessment for all cells in the data set difficult. No standard error maps were available.

Accuracy of this data set is based on the original specification of the Defense Mapping Agency (DMA) 1 degree digital elevation models (DEM) used to calculate the PRISM climatic data. The stated accuracy of the original DEMs are 130 m circular error with 90% probability.
dqReport.evalMethDesc: 130 meters with 90% probability is the stated production objective for the Defense Mapping Agency's products.

prcStep.stepDesc: Bioclimatic Variable Calculation GIS staff at the USGS Fort Collins Science center wrote Python programs to calculate each bioclimatic variable based on the techniques outlined by the World Clim group. For additional information see: http://www.worldclim.org/bioclim Bio 3 Isothermality: Isothermality is generally useful for tropical, insular, and maritime environments. Isothermality is derived by calculating the ratio of the mean diurnal range (Bio 2) to the annual temperature range (Bio 7), and then multiplying by 100. Isothermality therefore quantifies how large the day-to-night temperatures oscillate relative to the summer-to-winter (annual) oscillations. An isothermal value of 100 indicates the diurnal temperature range is equivalent to the annual temperature range, while anything less than 100 indicates a smaller level of temperature variability within a month relative to the year. A species distribution may therefore be influenced by larger or smaller fluctuations within a month relative to the year and this variable is useful for ascertaining such information. Values calculated using the following formula: Step 1. Divide Bio 2 (Mean Diurnal Range) by Bio 7 (Temperature Annual Range). Step 2. Multiply the result of Step 1 by 100.

prcStep.stepDesc: Data Processing at the USGS Fort Collins Science Center GIS staff at the USGS Fort Collins Science center performed several processing steps on the original climate inputs used to derive this data. All files were converted from ASCII format to Erdas Imagine files, files were defined with a map projection, and climate measurements were converted to millimeters for precipitation and degrees Celsius for temperature files. Due to errors in the original metadata provided by PRISM, USGS also developed new compliant metadata.
